p.line: Mr *** conceived of the project of drawing up the elements of physiology while
reading the works of Baron de Haller. For several months, he collected
what seemed to him appropriate or essential to put in these elements:
notes and extracts were jotted down on a few isolated pages. Death having
prevented Mr *** from realizing the project, for which he only happened to
prepare the material, these notes are believed to be united in a single
copy. No doubt incomplete, and despite their lack of order, it is thought
that the public will nevertheless receive these fragments with pleasure,
and that one day someone will undertake, after the plan and ideas of
Mr ***, the work he had only sketched.

div1.head: PART I: BEINGS

p.line: Nature has made only a very small number of beings that it has varied to
infinity, perhaps one alone by combination, mixture, and dissolution out
of which all others have been formed1.
One calls those beings contradictory whose organization is inconsistent
with the rest of the universe. Blind nature, which produces them,
exterminates them. She only lets those survive who can bear to coexist
with the general order [as her eulogists] 2.
The elements as isolated molecules have no properties of mass. Flame is
without light and heat; water, without humidity and elasticity; air is
nothing like we see. That’s why these elements do nothing in the body
when combined with other substances3.
It is necessary to classify beings: from the inert molecule, if it is
indeed inert, up to the living molecule, to the animal-plant, to the
microscopic-animal, to animal, to man.
The chain of beings is not ruptured by the diversity of its forms. Form
is often only a mask that deceives, and a seemingly absent link remains,
perhaps, in one known being, to whom the progress of comparative anatomy
has not yet been able to assign its true place4.
The butterfly is worm, caterpillar and butterfly. The mayfly, a chrysalis four
years. The frog begins as a tadpole. So many transformations escape us! I see
some are rapid enough, so why wouldn’t there be some with much longer periods?
Who knows what numbed molecules of animals become after their death?
The means of accurately classifying beings therefore can only be the fruit of
successive labors of a great number of naturalists: it will be difficult and
very slow. Let’s pay attention without rushing to judge.
In nature, duration is only a succession of actions; extension is the coexistence
of simultaneous actions. In understanding, duration is resolved into movement by
abstraction, and extension is resolved into rest, but rest and movement belong to
one body.
I cannot separate, even by abstraction, the place and the duration of existence:
these two properties are therefore essential to it.
Vegetation, life or sensibility, and animalization are three successive operations.
The vegetable realm could well be and may have been the first source of the animal
realm, and have also had its own place in the mineral realm, which emanates from
universal heterogeneous matter.
What is a plant? What is an animal? a coordination of infinitely active molecules,
a chaining (enchainement) of small forces that everything conspires (concourt) to
separate. It is not surprising, then, that these beings pass away so quickly.
Difference of the vegetable realm and the animal realm.
Mobility in animal principles; fixity in vegetable principles.
There are two effects of endeavor5 (nisus) conserved or destroyed. The gelatinous
substance of both shows a middle state between animal and plant.
What may produce vinegar, acids and salts, leeched on substances in fermentation? In
composites, where endeavor (nisus) is overabundant. Water destroys endeavor (nisus),
isolates its parts, and activates them.
Animalization of the vegetable.
A vegetable is produced by heat and fermentation. Vegetable matter is animalized in
a vessel. It is also animalized in me, and animalized in me, it is revegetalized
in the vessel; There is only a difference in forms.
In kneading paste for a long time and sprinkling it with water often, its vegetable
nature is removed and an animal nature is so approximated that, by such an analysis,
genuine products are given(mem. Of the academy of [Bologne]).
Contiguity of the vegetable realm with the animal realm.
In Italy Msr. Beccaria6, and in Strasbourg, Madame Keissel and Madame Mayer wanted
to understand the constituent parts of flour. They washed it with several liquids.
They separated it from starch. They withdrew a substance very much resembling an
animal substance. Immediately, Mr. Rouelle in Paris, Mr. Macquer and the most able
of chemists resumed these experiments, and took them as far as they could go. They
found that starch only contained, to put it nicely, the vegetable parts of the flour;
that in removing the starch, it remained a gluten that they called vegeto-animal.
All these parts are so interrelated, so connected together that they cannot be
separated: when starch is removed, it spreads out in all directions, but when it is
abandoned, it folds up on itself, and takes its initial form again, as does the
tissue of skin which gradually stretches out and tightens. If this gluten is burned,
it crumbles like flesh, and spreads an odor of animal matter.
Eels are in flour paste, in vinegar, in nielloed grain, in horned grain*. Open
small tumors, or galls of ergot, green and not ripe; open them with a sharp
and round needle, without penetrating (offenser) their interior cavity. Drop
some water there, and you will see eels inside, but large, living or dead, full
of eggs or of much smaller eels. They are colossal in comparison to those found
in the same, more adult, riper grain, or in ordinary ergotic grain already dry
and black. The large ones are mothers; they are seen laying their tiny eggs
with a very sensible, non-ambiguous organ (partie), perfectly characterizing their
sex.
Across the transparent film of these eggs, a tiny young eel is seen folding itself,
refolding, stirring, finally, breaking out of its husk, emerging and moving itself,
alive and sliding in water. Along with these mothers, larger males can be seen—by
the long, conical, mobile organ below their bodies.
Although dry, these eels take on movement and life again when moistened by a drop of
water. Needham has known the phenomenon, but he does not believe that these eels are
animals, and makes them vital beings9; Buffon, living organic molecules; Fontana
animals; Needham wants them to form either animals or vegetables united or collected
according to certain laws.
These threads or grain eels examined by Fontana were so dry, so fragile, that a sudden
splash of water, the lightest possible needle, or a point of a hair having placed them
in flour, reduced them to powder (I almost wish Fontana had finely ground them).
The eel from nielloed grain10 wiggles at both ends. It lives seven to eight weeks when
supplied with water.
The mushroom, through an analysis of volatile alkalis, deposits a characteristic sign
of the animal realm. The grain of a mushroom is also long-lived: it oscillates in
water, is moved, is agitated, avoids obstacles and seems to balance between the
animal realm and the vegetable realm before being fixed in the latter.
The muscipula dionea plant of Caroline extends its leaves to the ground in [pairs], and
[pivots]. These leaves are covered by papillae. If a fly rests on a leaf, this leaf
and its company are fermented, just as the oyster sensing and watching its prey, sucks
on it and only rejects it when it is exhausted of juices. It is an almost carnivorous
plant. I don’t doubt that it should deposit a volatile alkali under analysis.
There are ambiguous generations emanated from the animal realm, as there are ambiguous
generations emanated from the vegetable realm.
Zoophytes have only the feeling of life. Freshwater polyps have sentiment, life and
digestion, and are animal-plants11.
The reformed polyp tends to acquire its first form again. Does a thread really hamper it?
It plays a part: it (the polyp) remains and lives reformed as a plant.
Adanson12 was the first who perceived a peculiar movement in the aquatic plant called the
tremella13. He refused to assign life and sentiment to this plant, and consequently
animality; he leaves it a plant. Fontana* makes of this the passage from the vegetable
realm to the animal realm; according to him it is at the same time a true plant, a true
animal.
Where do the movements of the tremella come from? Neither from water, nor air, because
they occur in every sense in the water and air at rest: and they occur in every way,
and in an opposite manner to agitated water.United or separated, the threads follow opposite
directions, agitated beside small corpuscles in rest.
By a particular mechanism? Impossible. A particular mechanism makes the bird fly, the fish
swim: but between these movements and the infinite variety of spontaneity, there is a very
marked difference. Now this infinite variety that we attribute in other animals to life,
sensibility, to spontaneity, we see it all in the threads of the tremella and in a certain
way; because there is neither deceleration nor cessation, nor interruption for months, years:
they last as long as the plant lives and vegetates. The tremella and its threads are thus
living and sensible animals: its organic parts therefore obey sensibility (sensibilité).
Dry, it loses its movements; moist it regains them: it is born, and then dies discreetly.
The tremella is not a simple plant. It is a mound of small plants, or vegetable threads,
which united together, form the plant with this name.
There is no one who, seeing the phenomena it offers, and who ignores that its threads are
the threads of a vegetable, should not at once pronounce that these threads are living
worms. The doubt only arises when you are told that these threads are portions of
vegetables, but this doubt quickly vanishes.
The phenomena (to add) from the sensitive14.
In plants there is a particular place that touching causes the erection and the effusion of
seed. This place is not the same for all. Male plants and female plants are distinguished.
There are some hermaphrodites.
In the tree, the roots become stems, and the stems become roots.

div1.div3:
Chapter II Animal.
The animal, according to some authors, is a hydraulic machine15. What foolishness can be spoken following this one presupposition!
The laws of movement of hard bodies are unknown, because there are not perfectly hard bodies16. The laws of movement of elastic bodies are not any more
certain17, because there are no perfectly elastic bodies. The laws of movement of fluid bodies are everywhere precarious, and the laws of movement of sensible, animated,
organized, living, are not even sketched.
He who in the calculus of this last type of movement omits sensibility (sensibilité), irritability (irritablité), life, spontaneity (spontaneité), does not know what he does.
A rough body acts on a sensible, organized, animal body; the latter is conscious of it, or has the feeling of impression[, and often the place of impression. It is tickled or wounded; it wants or does not want to be moved. How? By what laws?
